	(! surely a c4-clef is missing at the new line at the last syllable of Oculus: the c4 added at mira, where text is also added, should have been continued. The wrong c-clef is maintained for the next three lines and the verse. This is a less drastic solution than any other. On the basis of this correction, the pitches from -lus and for the verse are transcribed a fifth lower than in the source, where the melody ends on 5 or C. This involves leaps of a fifth up and down at -lus nam.)

  ®MDBO¯    |.CL11 (X CLARA) [n1]
       |g1 [Information]
       (B AH 5 #54)
       (Ms 1 :GMB Clm 23291 f.103v-19 {Box 88})
  [not a superior Ms: clefs, etc., not well placed. Repetenda cues missing.]

®MDIT¯(9e O holy actions of the most holy father, Edmund, renowned king and martyr, who was made a victim to God: today he was accepted as a sacrifice on behalf of his people into the scent of sweetness and praise. Hence, praise and glory to God, to his Christ and the Holy Spirit. )®MDNM¯
®PG¯
®TP0¯®RHA®FL¯®TS25C¯®DAyy/m/d¯	®PN¯®LD ¯[X EL60 Elisabeth]



¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
	(X EL60 Elisabeth of Hungary)
	(B Barbara Haggh * Two Offices for Elizabeth of Hungary * The Institute of Mediaeval Music, Ottawa, Canada, 1995) [this is an edition of EL61 and EL63 from the Cambrai manuscript referred to under EL63 below.]
	[Professor Haggh's edition of EL61 varies in many details from the transcription and encoding here, done from the two manuscripts noted below. The variants are too extensive to record fully. A few important variants are recorded.]
	[The encoding of EL63 was done many years ago. The Cambrai manuscript is the only presently known source with chant for this office: since this manuscript is clearly legible, the encoding and Professor Haggh's edition rarely differ. In a few places, my reading varies slightly. These variants are recorded.]
	[In the manuscript database of LMLO are some 130 references to an office for Elisabeth. In the score that I have been able to check in detail, I have yet to discover a source of EL63 other than the Cambrai book and the three Breviaries listed in Analecta Hymnica. A rubric in the Cambrai manuscript {see below} suggests that it is the old office, for which EL61 is a replacement.]

	[this code allows the software to distinguish repertories:] (z @r)
®MDBO¯ 	|.EL61 (X ELISABETH) [n1]
	|g1 [Information]
	(B AH 25 #90)
	[Not in Humbert's]
	(Ms 1 :CBU 626 f.268-73)
	(Ms 2 :GTS 1684 {395a} {Box 108})
 8=1119 (= V=A5RE M=secular L=A5E W=E V=R W=E {altern.})
	[Haggh's edition conforms to this order except for VR {which is identical to MR9}, and up to second vespers, where her edition has W=AE: the A is the E of this encoding: the E is the alternative Magnificat antiphon encoded here, "O beata sponsa"]
	(6# V=12345{6}.5 M=4.123{1,3,3}456{5,6,6F}781{7,8,5F} L=45678.5 W=.4 V={8G} W=.6)
 ,w (, widow)
 13 (+1231) (c1235)
 :H :G (:H) (:G.Thuringia)
 5.OFM (5)

®MDBO¯	|.GO71 (X GORGONIUS) [n1]
	|g1 [Information]
(B AH 26 #24)
(ms :GTB 521)
	(64 hard to tell whether the little tail that ends some neumes is a plica or merely a pen flourish)
 8=0311 8=0312 8=0222? (= V=E M=secular  L=A5E W=E)
	(6# V=.1 M=7.123{1,2,3}456{4,5,6}781{7,8,4} L=12345.6 W=.1)
	(6 not heavily melismatic, but uses a wide range)
	(6^ clefs: low C is represented by the letter C on the space !)
	(6^ clefs: upper g and middle c sometimes used. The f-line below this g is also marked with a {coloured ?} line)
	(64 from MR6 there seem to be new repercussive neumes, like double commas)
 ,m (, martyr)
(&Bruno of Toul, probably before being made pope in 1048)

®MDUL¯(9e The Greek emperor, having been oppressed in battle and weakened by the army of the barbarians, asks the help of the glorious martyr, when suddenly, the saint of the Christians appears and the illustrious signbearer, preceding them, shattered the hostile army.)®MDNM¯
	(e Reiss attriius)

¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
	[this code allows the software to distinguish repertories:] (z @r 12c?)
®MDBO¯	|.OS91 (X OSWALDUS) [n1]
	|g1 [Information]
	(B AH 13 #81)

®MDBO¯	|.OT01 (X Oswin, king)
	|g1 [Information]
	(Ms 1 :EOCX 134 {Box 186})
 5.mon 8=0820 (= {-} M=R3E.R4 L=A5E P=A T=A {-} N=A)
	(6# M={6c,7,8,}6c{1,3,7,6c} L=12356c{6}.7 H=146c V=136c{6c}.6c Q=1236c12245 M={1,2,3,4,5,6c,7,8,1,7,6c} V={1}.6c ...)
	(=t0311)
	(= + A9 for ferias, etc.)

®MDNM¯

¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
	[this code allows the software to distinguish repertories:] (z @r)
®MDBO¯	|.SG61 (X SIGISMUNDUS) [n1]
	|g1 [Information]
(B AH 5 #79)
(ms :QPlSe 7)
	(6 underlay in ms is often very unclear)
	(v many differences with the AH text)
	(v ms has alleluias for many texts: not added to text lines here)
 8=0501 (= V=AE M=IA3R3 L=A5E W=RE Q=A)
	(6# V=1.6c M=5.123{1,1,5} L=12345.6c W={5}.8 Q=6)
 ,k ,m (, king martyr)
 :C (:CP)
 14 (t1354) (t1366)
®MDNM¯
	|g2 [Names]
	(#&)
/ &sigismunde.1.-0.10-.* &sigismunde.1.-0.10-.* &sigismundE.345.432121.212.3; &sigismundI.4.3.4.5; &sigismundo.32'34.42'31.0.1 &sigismundO.4.5.565.5; &sigismunduS.10.-1.121.1; &sigismunduS.10.3.45.5; &sigismundus.123.324323.13'56.5 &sigismunduS.5.4.565.3; /()
	(#:)
/ :burgundis.7.4.5 :burgundorum.10.*.01.1 /()

®MDBO¯	|.SG61=V ®MDNM¯

¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯

	[this code allows the software to distinguish repertories:] (z @r)
®MDBO¯	|.TH21 (X THOMAS Becket, of Canterbury) [n1]
	|g1 [Information]
	(B AH 13 #92)
	(ms 1 :TEU 123 flyleaves {Box 112})
[gothic, but excellent]
[ms 1 seems to have b naturals where other sources have flats !: and to have repercussives and plicas more than others ?]
	(ms 2 :FPA 1116 {photostats})
	(ms 3 :EOB lat. lit. b 14)
 5.mon 8=1229 (= V=EE M=monastic'Q' L=A5E W=E + V=E M=A4R3)
	(6# V=.11 M=2.123456c{1,2,3,1}781238{5,6c,7,8}5{3,1,6c,2}'5' L=1236c8.6c W=.1 + V=.1 M=1532{818})
[widespread secular version]
	(ms 4 :ECFw 369 {Box 112})
[ms 4 not a very reliable source q]
	(ms: numerous others: :EOB rawl. lit. e.45; :EOB e.mus.2; etc.)
	(v numerous and usually small, occasionally textual)

	(ms 1 :ELB 28598, f.123v-5v {Box 116}, with chant)
	(6 this manuscript is careless: notes are placed on the stave so that their pitch is ambiguous; text is underlaid very haphazardly; rubrics and some words are erased; flats sometimes look like upward plicated pitches)

¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
	[!!!! the variants here have gone beyond what this format can really handle. To highlight the important points in the data, the ASCII block 221 Ý marks all responsories, as noted in the text of LMLO: Sources and Chant.]
	(z @p<@r) [prose texts set to tunes from rhymed sources]
	[the variants in ms 2 are from a manuscript of the Roman Curia: the repertory code is changed for these, to @p RC]
®MDBO¯	[Not in Humbert's]
	|.XCX0 70=XCX [Corpus Christi]
	|g1 [Information]
	(ms 1 :FPN 1143) (ms holograph ?)
	(ms 2 :EOB Can. lit. 379, f.9 {Franciscan})
	(ms 3 edited in Mathiesen ®MDUL¯Journal of Musicology®MDBO¯)
	(ms 4 :CBU 626)
	(Ms 5 :BBR 139, f.107-9: has 10 responsories, in this order ...)
	(Ms 5 + 1 2 10 5 7 6 11 12 9 and =VR. Modal order: 125576c1715)
	(Ms 5 + also "une sort d'invitatoire rime" {Lambot, p.68} ...)
	[and modern sources]
(9e translation in Divine Office, Liturgical Press, Minn. v.2, p.1453)
	(v lines with variants show only variant words: the remaining chantwords are identical. Normally minor non-pitch variants such as accidentals are not shown.)
	(v NB dislocation of syllables and words among the sources: this may be a function of the editor's decision regarding underlay !)
	(v m2 has fewer repercussives; not a careful ms)
	($ ! tunes adapted from other offices: rubrics given below)
	[is this why tunes vary so greatly: they're not copied from any one authorised source, but merely from a source specified by ®MDUL¯contra®MDBO¯, etc.]

	(= V=A5RE M=secular H=R3 L=A5E W=E + M=A3R3)

	(B 1 Auda {1923})
	(6 transcribed from Auda. Note by Dr Terry Brown: this version seems remarkably consistent in its use of plicas on certain consonants and diphthongs. Is it a sanitized edition? Compare the encoding of the version in Humbert's Antiphonal)

/1 quique terrigene et filii hominum simul in unum dives et pauper /()

®TP0¯®RHA®FL¯®TS25C¯®DAyy/m/d¯ ®PN¯®LD ¯[Nat., Sunday within the octave]


¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯

®TP0¯®RHA®FL¯®TS25C¯®DAyy/m/d¯ ®PN¯®LD ¯[Lent, Ash Wednesday: feria iv]


¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
	[season: ] ®MDBO¯|F_Lent_beginning [XL] ®MDNM¯
®MDBO¯	|.0.AW (K 4=L=w 5=XL.0=w) .f,iv
	(Ash Wednesday Capite ieiunii) (f.246 col.2) Ý

	|.0.AW=L ®MDNM¯

®TP0¯®RHA®FL¯®TS25C¯®DAyy/m/d¯ ®PN¯®LD ¯[Lent, Holy Week, feria vi, Good Friday]


¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
®MDBO¯	|.6{GF} (K 5=XL.6=y {GF}) .f,vi.GF
	(f.255v col.2) Ý

	|.6{GF}=M ®MDNM¯

  ®TP0¯®RHA®FL¯®TS25C¯®DAyy/m/d¯ ®PN¯®LD ¯[1st Sunday after Trinity]
  
  
  ¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
       [season: ] ®MDBO¯|F_Trinity_Sundays [Tri.Sun] ®MDNM¯
  ®MDBO¯    |.1 (K 7=Tri.1) =d
       (f.270 at foot of col.2) |
  
       |.1=L ®MDNM¯
       |g19 =LE.1d
  / homO quidam erat dives et induebatur purpura et bysso et epulabatur cotidie splendide
  et erat quidam mendicus nomine lazarus qui iacebat ad ianuam eius ulceribus plenus
  cupiens saturari de micis que cadebant de mensa divitis et nemo illi dabat sed et canes
  veniebant et lingebant ulcera eius / alleluia /()
  \ homo.1.10; quidam.1.3 erat.3.2 dives.12.10 et.3 induebatur.4.5.43.4.45 purpura.3.2.1
  et.4 bysso.4343.1 et.1 epulabatur.3.2.4.54.3 cotidie.3.32.4.32 splendide.1.01.1 et.5
  erat.5.43 quidam.4.5 ^ mendicus.76.45.51 nomine.34.2.32 lazarus.1.01.1 qui.0
  iacebat.1.3.2. ad.1 ianuam.3.2.1 eius.121=0,.10 ulceribus.01.3454.21.232 plenus.1.1
  cupiens.5.4.5 saturari.5.4.5.4 de.3 micis.45'7=4=35.54321 que.0 cadebant.1.3.2 de.1
  mensa.3.4 divitis.3.2.1 et.4=3 nemo.454.3210 illi.1.232 dabat.1.1 sed.5 et.432 canes.45.5

®TP0¯®RHA®FL¯®TS25C¯®DAyy/m/d¯ ®PN¯®LD ¯[Catharine of Alexandria]


¯®TS10,20,30,40,50,60¯
	[this code allows the software to distinguish repertories:] (z @r OP)
®MDBO¯	|.CthrnA 8=1125 (K 1125 CB20 Cthrn;A) ,v ,m
	(f.310 mid col.2) Ý
	(= V=A.E M=I.R#3R#6R#9 L=A5.E W=.E)
	(6# V=1.1 M=4.{1}{6}{8} L=13757.1 W=.6c)
	($ rhymed office textual concordances: the relationships between the various offices for Catharine are too complex to attempt to outline here. Other transcriptions are available in separate files. Some chants are quite different, especially in lauds. One versions of =LE, for example, has an identical intonation, then quite different tune.)
